Summary:Suits: A Business RPG is an RPGMaker game that has set price to a euro. As there are many bad RPGMaker games and bad cheap games, that doesn't sounds much appealing, right? This game is actually a big surprise!

By the terms of gameplay, it's still the good old system we know from, for example, Final Fantasy. But what makes this game great is the ubiquitous jokes and critics that aren't just about business sphere - They have made jokes of almost everything! Undertale-like puns? Check. Gaming critique? Check. Culture references? Check. Political humour? Check. Controversial humour? Check!

This game is here for a price of a cheap coffee, offering few hours full of fun and entertainment. You won't regret buying this if you don't mind the gameplay and crazy graphics.

Pros:- Jokes in every corner.
- Unique graphics style. It's lazy style but it perfectly fits the comedy that the game offers.
- Very low price.
- Steam achievements.

Cons:- JRPG grinding. Some places feel a little like a Zubat cave. But it's not that bad here as in other (serious) games of the genre. I was still missing something like Repel.

An RPG involving you as a businessman, your mission in this black and white, dreary world is to slowly go into corruption.

I can't believed that I've paid just 47p for this amazing game, I would've paid £4-5 for this and would've been more than happy to!

If you can set aside the art (which I love, it gives the game a depressing feel to it), and you love RPGs then seriously just go for it! The music itself, well there's barely any but that's a good advantage for this game! It's meant to make you think about this world and how horrible it is, knowing that it's all about the money and screw anyone who thinks differently (even just a tad!).

The gameplay is just spot on; you're able to navigate around multiple worlds from the hub when unlocked and each area has its own look. The battle sequence is the usual turn by turn RPG style, but that's certainly not a bad thing at all! In fact, I'm glad that the battles are like this, as it makes me nostalgic.

The writing, my GOD the WRITING! If you see this, TALK TO EVERY PERSON AND EXPLORE THE WORLD!!! The humor in this is glorious, taking its own environment and making little jokes about it (for example, a person very early in the game is called Loanrenzo)! not only this, but it references so many memes that are currently popular, such as Tai from Youtube (fuel units), Donald Trump (small loan of a million dollars), the clocks reading 4:20 and many more! Many a chuckle was had while playing this lovely gem of a game.

I'm still not finished with this game yet, as I've only played for about an hour at this moment of time but my goodness it's amazing, I mean, why are you still reading this review? BUY IT!

reviewText: Trapped in a nearly suffocating world of dry pessimism, nonsensical humor, boring combat, lagging controls, and dull visuals: that's what it's like to play Suits. Admittedly, this was accomplished well with the intial plot, but it couldn't make up for the rest of the experience, which just wasn't fun.  Again, perhaps that's the point - but this is supposed to be an interesting RPG, so there needs to be more redeeming qualities.\n\nThings I still liked: the plot, creative graphics despite budget art, the concept.

reviewText:
TL;DR: If you hate constant internet culture jokes and references, this game is probably not for you. Otherwise, pretty good.

Suits is a short RPG maker game heavily inspired by OFF. As one can see by the other reviews, the game's main selling point is its dark humor and the references it makes. The game refuses to take itself seriously all the way to the very end, and that can actually hurt the game's story at some points, even though the plot itself is pretty simple.
The artstyle and the music are very unique and go along pretty well, strengthening the game's unsettling atmosphere.

The gameplay is alright, but could use some improvement. There's a ton of secrets and optional events to find in every single area, which gives Suits some replay factor, but the battles are a bit too simplistic. Even though each character feels very different from the other two, the entire game can be beaten by using the same combination of 2-3 commands, only stopping every now and then to heal your party, but thankfully the game ends before this can become too repetitive.

With all that said, though, this is definitely one of the most unique and interesting RPG maker games on Steam, and definitely worth every cent. I really hope to see a sequel in the future.

reviewText: The biggest drawback to this game, in my opinion, is the combat system. I'm a fan of turn-based combat in general, but this was terribly monotonous. This was mostly because it rarely seemed good to actually use your skills. The main character's regular attack quickly started doing about as much damage as his lowest cost offensive skill, and fights were generally over by the time I'd saved up enough TP for higher leveled ones. The first supporting character came with skills to attack all enemies at once, but the vast majority of the time I was fighting single opponents. Buffs and debuffs also felt to me like a waste of a turn in this game, although I might have just not had the right strategy. Most of the time, this wasn't too bad, but it made any area with random encounters feel like a pain just to slog through.\n\nThe story is interesting enough to keep me engaged regardless of the combat. I'd say the writing can often be heavyhanded. There were times I got the impression that it was trying to hard to explain the joke/satire, which often ruined it. That said, there were also moments that worked really well and made me laugh, and also monsters that were unique. I'd recommend fans of RPGMaker-style games give it a shot.

reviewText:
So after completing everything there is to complete in this game, I can say that this was certainly worth the $0.65 that I paid for it, and I would recommend it at it's low price. Plus, I sold the trading card drops for $0.52, I believe? So, it was kind of only $0.13.

That said, while the game has potential and charm, it's got plenty of very strange design choices and features that don't seem to work right. The most annoying of them being that interacting with objects takes place on the tiles around them, rather than the objects themselves. This means that unless you're standing in the right spot, nothing will happen when you search a crate, or look at something, which makes you think that nothing is supposed to happen. The art is pretty rough, but it's unique, at least. Anyone that avoids using RPG Maker's default assets deserves some credit. Soundtrack is wacky but enjoyable. Story is... something...

One of the game's stronger points is probably it's use of references and humor. There were plenty of moments that I had a genuine laugh at.

I've seen people imply that it's on the same level as LISA, and that's not even close to the truth, but I did enjoy my time with it. I'd definitely check out a sequel, as long as the price was kept as low as this was.

I convinced a friend to finally install steam just for this game. 10/10 Would seductivly slide sandwiches again.

Ok in all seriousness, I picked this game up on a whim, its ridiculously low price sort of helped me feel comfortable picking it up. I'm very glad I did.
Suits a business RPG is a role playing game where you take up the role of a businessman who just graduated from business school. Since cooperations rule the planet in this universe.
For me the humor was on point and reminds me a bit of Rick and Morty, just enough dark humor and unexpected twists in it that makes it funny for me. 4th wall breaking, Easter eggs, and dark humor.
Gameplay wise it reminds me of Earthbound. There is some level grinding and yes there is no free healing, however that is usually how this genre of RPG works. There is some grinding, but I never got tired of it, mostly because I kept wandering around into random peoples' houses.
Usually I don't like bringing up the graphics since that is never the selling point for me, however I think it fits the dystopian 1984 vibe the developers were going for. The hand drawn backgrounds makes the game a bit more memorable in my eyes.
Honestly the best part about this game besides the concept and humor is the exploration. I usually just wander around and loot everything in sight. Which leads me to discover things, I won't spoil anything since playing this game without knowing anything that pops up is satisfying.
Also it is not an Undertale clone, I know my Undertale playtime isn't much, but I have played on another friend's account quite a bit to understand the gameplay and mechanics. They are similar only because of the genre they are in. 2D turn based RPGs. It is like saying every tennis video game ever conceived is a rip off of pong. Or every FPS is a ripoff of Doom. (Note: Undertale is an awesome game, I still highly recommend it, I just saw people calling this game a ripoff.)

My final verdict:
Suits is a good game, although humor is
probably going to fuel most of your enjoyment if you don't like the visuals or gameplay. So Suits isn't for everyone, but it is very lowly priced so honestly it is worth a shot. Plus steam refund exists now if you really really don't like the game that much.

reviewText:
Let me start out by noting Suits is a game inspired by OFF, a game by Mortis Ghost. In all honesty, I liked OFF a little more, but I did enjoy this game. For a dollar, it's totally worth it, even if it's only a couple hours long.

The gameplay itself wasn't very inspired. I found myself using the same three strategies the entire game: Use Staple Down to disable strong, single enemies, use Staple Storm to beat groups, and attack the rest of the time. Ultimately, you should sail through it, as long as you be sure to get the best equips at all times. One interesting note is that most of your funds come from doing optional things, rather than only battling. That's pretty cool, because it gives you a reason to explore a little, even thought it's not exactly a vast world.

The visuals are very unique and interesting, but if you don't love the general uniqueness, you'll likely hate it, because it's all drawn in black and white. The music is pretty good actually, though not good enough to go searching Youtube for it. Overall, I'd say these are both nice for what they are.

The most important thing is the adventure, despite everything previously mentioned. The story is an interesting social commentary, with witty bits of comedy scattered through the entire game. The generallly cynical atmosphere is a great change of pace, and the whole game experience is one huge satirical parody of the greed and corruption of those in power and the mundane lives people are programmed to live, working as small cogs their whole lives for these powers. It's really frightening to have to accept this reality, but it's unfortunately accurate. People are expected to live as workers. As for the corporate and political corruption, that's all true as well, just not to a degree where society is openly a place where justice is bought, the poor are used as spare parts and people are punished for not buying things. You cannot deny that there are scandals, however. I believe the CEO of McDonald's once stated that if any of his competitors were to drown, he'd put a hose in their mouth.

To wrap things up, this game is not expensive at all and a very unique experience, and I would reccommend it for those reasons.

This is a game that I randomly decided to buy as it was only 47p at time of purchase, and to be honest this game feels like it would be around £6.99 price tag.

Suits: A Business RPG is seriously worth picking up for a fun RPG that lasts around 4 to 5 hours. While I didn't get many of the references/ jokes that were in this game, it kept me going as the plot was personally very interesting (Personally the game felt like earthbound while I was playing through it).

The gameplay is basically Turn based RPG (like Final Fantasy) where you select your character and he can attack the enemy/ boss. The other moves your characters can do are special attacks which use up a bit of your TP (Tech points) or FU (Fuel), which can either buff up your party members or debuff/ attack enemy's. reviewText:
TL;DR: A decent RPGMaker game with a fairly unique art style and aesthetic. Nothing outstanding about it, but the low price point and short play time means it doesn't overstay its welcome.

The first point of comparison to this game comes easily to OFF, an RPGMaker game made with a similar aesthetic style. The comparisons are really only skin deep though, as the game itself is much shallower than its inspiration. While the inspiration for this game is freely available and this costs about a dollar, it doesn't mean you should pass this up entirely.

It is clear that this is not a work of laziness at all. The art style is consistent and the enemies encountered tend to be fairly unique, with the exceptions of random encounter areas and a few repeated enemies. The sprites and hand drawn works fit well together, and nothing looks jarringly out of place. The only offense art wise is that practically all encounters start by talking to a generic looking suited dude, who turns out to be something far more interesting in the combat screen. Some of them could have used unique sprites, but that is a small complaint.

Game-play is bog standard. You start with one character, and can acquire two more through a bit of exploration. Notably, the first party member is easily missed if you don't take the time to get him, and he can be lost forever, just like the second one. If the game suffers anywhere, it is that the game is exceedingly easy if you have a remote skill at RPGs. Every encounter, boss or not, can be solved by a combination of the second characters staple ability to paralyze them, and then wailing on them till it needs repeating. Some healing might be required, but the game doles out cash and healing/recovery items quite often. Any more complex strategies are not needed, and there are no elements or weaknesses to worry about, and very few buffs get used outside boss self-buffs or debuffs. No grinding is really necessary, but the game could have used some variety in the challenge, as there is really nothing to differentiate bosses from each other, other than attack animations and some spikes in damage.

The story is clearly trying to style itself after OFF, with that weird world-vibe, dystopian appeal, and twisted characters in battle. The main way it falters is that the game really doesn't build on the world at all. OFF has characters telling tales to you as you go through the areas, and its clear the place has a mythology. This game attempts that, but so much of its writing is spent telling one-off pop culture jokes and references that any potential world building is lost. Half of your encounters are jokes or references to something, when the game time could have been spent building the world. Where OFF tells a story of a world where everything is, well, off, this game tells a story about a world where everything is a reference that will become dated in time, with a vague plot about huge faceless corporations and drones beneath.

In summary, the game is short, cheap, and doesn't overstay its welcome. It hints at a sequel, and it would be nice if they built on what they have to be more than pop-culture references, but that is not in this game. Buy it, play it for four hours or so to fully complete it, and decide for yourself if you want to give the developers a chance to further develop it.

reviewText:
A simple, yet surreal little RPG heavily inspired by OFF.  You play as The Guy (no really), just another Suit in Suit City, where Corporations run everything and your worth begins and ends with your work output.  What begins as a simple job to sue an uncooperative potential buyer quickly spirals into a conspiracy and civil war, with you stuck in the middle.

Gameplay is the standard RPG Maker combat.  Its turnbased, and the enemies are surprisingly colorful, varied and unique.  Most of the enemies are handplaced and unique.  In fact, random encounters don't actually become commonplace until halfway through the game after a certain plot development.

The game really shines in its writing.  It is an unapologetic pastiche of capitalism, materialism, and other kinds of -isms.  Its wacky, surreal, and surprisingly dark at times.

Its short, but given the low low price its acceptable.  If you want a quick, quirky and fun RPG, give it a go.  Its literally pocket change.

I spent a sick day playing Suits and I have to say that that sick day was one of the best I've had recently. I was able to complete Suits in about 4 hours, however those 4 hours were quite dense with content. The art style of Suits is akin to OFF, Space Funeral(2 tablets to paradise), and Thank God for the Rain(never completed). The gameplay is like a typical RPGMaker game, so it's not overly complicated in any way. You don't have to grind very much, and if you buy the equipment upgrades every now and again, you'll be fine. There's a handful of silly political missions to be done if you take up the jobs offered by the left and right wings in some areas, but what I found to be the most interesting political aspect of Suits is that the game seems to take a more bipartisan stance (well, okay, there WERE some marxist themes to be fair...) to politics and focuses more on The Guy's process of detangling the grip of an unregulated, dominating corporation(stick it to the man, man.) on Suits City. It seems to paint politics as a side issue to a larger one at hand, rather than weaving a less than subtle political agenda into it.
I found the save feature to be amusing, but would've liked a health/FU/MP restore upon save like other RPGMaker games, but that's not entirely necessary as you can restore your health easily with some disposable income. You can also skip one of the tasks if you take the secret passage in one of the bushes to the left of the W. bank if you want to get into the bank in the Financial district faster.
My favorite songs (in the BGM folder) would have to be WallPuncher, AdvancedSharkness, and PainStation; each were catchy but unique while supplying the game's environment with an almost ambient sense of dread.

Or maybe it's just Marxist overthrow simulator....

Lastly, check out the bushes on top of the office building for a fun little reference, go into the painting, and of course THANK YOU BASED MJ

The story definitely has some great moments, although is somewhat incoherent in places. In my playthrough the F12 hadn't been fixed so trying to take a screenshot with F12 would result in the game going back to the main menu and me having to start again from my latest save - this should definitely be fixed.

In summary I found the game enjoyable for its price and found that the humor and art in itself was worth it. I spent roughly 5 hours to complete it (and it appears I missed a few things), but I took my time so it can probably be beaten faster than that,

If you like odd RPGs and aren't offended by the artstyle then I'll definitely recommend this for the low price.

Suits is an average yet interesting RPG.

It starts on the premise that you live in a world inhabitated only by office workers and their bosses, creating a world dominated by ceaceless work and exxagerated consumerism.
You play as a new employee for this world and get instantly thrown into it.

From this point on you can expect the usual RPG standards when it comes to exploration and combat, with classic turn-based battles, items and such.

There isn't much to say about the gameplay, except for a completely new but relatively small mechanic: the P2W.
The 'pay to win' attack literally throws money to your enemies to instakill them, but it is a risky move, because the entire game and your ability to get through it depends on how much money you have.
I thought that it was really interesting that the game revolves around money rather than traditional RPGs, wich usually rely on EXP points and high levels to defeat bosses.
You will have to administrate it well tough, because every boss is more expensive than the last, and they are very difficult to defeat by normal means (unless you grind, that is). This particular thing made me struggle a lot because you never know when you will need to use the money to win a battle and when to save it, because not only you need money to defeat hard enemies, but also to heal yourself, since there are no inns or similar ''healing centres''.
This ''The money is important and you use it for everything'' type of RPG is something I had necver seen before, but it doesn't really make up for the rest of the boring battles, uninspired combat (besides this P2W thing) and a lack of party members and items.

This said about the combat sistem, the visuals are boring and the music is terribly bland, attempting to recreate an office atmosphere, and it succeeds at it, wich isn't a actually a good thing, because it makes almost every scenario in the game look like the same and it creates a very tedious to explore world.
There are some exceptions, like  the drug trip  , but it doesn't make up to make an interesting world.

A minor bunch of bugs and glitches, but nothing important.

I give this game a 5.5/10 counting the humor (wich relies heavily on memes, but sometimes gives a good grin) and the price ( I mean, 1€ isn't a big deal).
So yeah, go ahead and buy if you have a couple hours to kill.

Suits: A Business RPG is a new RPGMaker RPG designed by Technomancy Studios. That's the standard stuff out of the way, so let's get into the weird.  Suits starts you off as The Guy, another businessman in line to join the ranks in a world run entirely by corporations, built as corporations. The satire of consumerism and greed is done well, and helps to add to the game's very offbeat sense of humor. The jokes range from the clocks always set to 4:20 as it's simplest, to ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ on a dinosaur's floor at its strangest. This, along wth the setting and atmosphere is what I think makes Suits such a fun game; it's absurd while still being relevant to modern times. The Payday 2 microtransactions joke is a good example, and is done well. The story itself is rather straightforward; notes are placed around to provide back story and clues and the ending sums up the purpose of the world itself and your actions nicely. Oh, and the art and music. Some people were put off by the crude sketch design and music; personally I found them both surrelastic, funny and disturbing enough that they made a perfect fit for the plot.\n\nTo sum it up, Suits is a straightforward PRG mechanically; there are some special abilities like a instant kill that only works 1% of the time, and being able to pay your enemies to lose. There's not much that changes the gameplay itself from other RPG's; instead the focus is on the creative art of the game. Whether you'll like this or not will depend on what you're looking for in an RPG game, but for it's price it's got a decent story length to it and potential for follow up. A simple bare bones indie rpgmaker game, with inspirations from OFF. Got the game for a song and I thought it was worth the price.

You play an all purpose businessman in an exaggerated black and white capitalist universe, where everything is a satire of everything that goes along with the nature of economics, politics, entertainment, etc. Enemies are hand drawn in a rough style, with some of them being parodies of real world people. There's a great deal of 420 humor, references, and some ♥♥♥♥ jokes. I found a lot of it just blurred together.

You can control up to 3 unspeaking characters, although I was able to finish the non-joke ending with just 2, as the third arrives very late in the game. Outside of one or two moments, the game is not hard whatsoever. Combat is extremely simple and requires little to no resource hoarding, nor tactics. I wasn't a fan of that- it's a little too basic. I got through the entire game with just my main character auto attacking and my one side character doing an ability with a single crowd control effect, with the rare occasion of using an area effect attack. You don't really get interesting abilities and a LOT of what you have is too expensive to use more than one or twice without reloading resources out of battle, but you don't really need those abilities either.

At about 4 hours long, taking my time, but not grinding anything for xp, the game is of fair length for the price. It's not an amazing title in the sense of other really 'out there' indie games like OFF, Yume Nikki, or Space Funeral, but it's fair for what it is and I don't think it's trying to be anything more than that. And that's really just how Suits is. It's not terribly interesting to read the text in the game and the imagery is fairly dull, but it's not bad either. It's just average. I am, however, figuring the price of the game into this. You get what you pay for, and for that, it's quite fair. I didn't mind playing it, it just didn't 'wow'.

Suits, for me at least, feels a lot like Earthbound, can't really explain why. The both games are a bit weird, that's why I liked Earthbound in the first place, too.
I find the hand drawn dystopian-themed scenery and characters appealing and their designs inspiring. The gameplay is simple, and so is the story.
You traverse the Suits City to reach the top, going through it's every district.
Each district has a certain theme to it, and loads of satire. The game is a satire to everything, and yet I found the satire a bit lacking. Don't get me wrong, it was fun, but I think it could have been a bit bolder with the jokes, especially at the Media District.
It's great for it's asking price, I just can't not recommend it.
